Lucian Grainge said: Innovation breeds success, and in television, John de Mol 's track record is second to none. He evidently has another winner with The Voice of format. confederation, Susanna Camusso , insisted that the referendum "shows that there is no possibility of ruling a factory without the consensus of the workers." Industry Minister Maurizio Sacconi predicted the decision would encourage investment in Italian industry. The outcome of the referendum opens an evolution in industrial relations, especially in large factories that should allow a better use of the plants and a real increase in salaries, Maurizio Sacconi told Italian state radio. Sergio Marchionne had pledged to link pay increases to productivity. But the flexible work rules also limit the right to strike during full production, and reduce break times and sick pay. Unions

a recent Gallup Poll. Presidents Jimmy Carter ( 45.3 percent), Ronald Reagan ( 43.3 percent) and Bill Clinton ( 45.9 percent) had lower approval rating averages during their second years in office, Gallup reports. Barack Obama 's low second-year ratings are due in large part to the struggles of the U.S. economy, Jeffrey M. Jones wrote for Gallup. "The other presidents with low second-year averages also took office during difficult economic times. Jimmy Carter Secretary of State Colin Powell said Barack Obama has made some achievements, but said Barack Obama must focus on job creation- the Bill Clinton 's most challenging task. "We didn't elect Superman," Michael Hansen said

Allen Iverson had 32 points and 12 assists Wednesday night, and the Nuggets used a late run to beat the Grizzlies 106-102. This was a big win for us at somebody else's home, Allen Iverson said. "Down seven points with 3 minutes to go. It was a gut check for us. I think a game like this is going to help us down the road." Elias Says Allen Iverson

The Daily Caller reports Rep. Mike Pence ( R-IN), a possible contender for president in 2012, has announced that he will NOT run for the White House: As reported by the Indianapolis Star, Mike Pence has circulated a letter to supporters announcing the decision. "In the choice between seeking national office and serving Indiana in some capacity, we choose Indiana," wrote Mike Pence . "We will not seek the Republican nomination for president in 2012."
